Award.AwardTitle: The Academic Community for Engineering Students (ACES)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of the project, a joint effort between the University of Virginia (UVa) and Thomas Nelson Community College (TNCC), is to increase the number of students earning engineering baccalaureate degrees. There is an emphasis on increasing the number of graduates from underrepresented populations in engineering, primarily through the implementation of a set of proven and innovative activities designed to increase retention rates. The minimum projected program outcomes are to increase the UVa's 1st to 2nd year retention from 88% to 96% and its 5-year graduation rate from 72% to 80% and to increase TNCC transfer and three-year graduation rates from 50% to 58% over the course of the grant period. Project activities for UVa first-year and transfer students include a summer bridge program, engineering excellence workshops, an engineering peer mentoring program, a transfer student network, and a creative engineering design course. Activities for TNCC students include a professional development workshop, a UVa-to-TNCC advising and mentoring program, and a UVa-TNCC summer laboratory research program. Joint activities are an engineering open houses/community college day, campus visits, and an engineering seminar series. Also, both institutions will host social events aimed at fostering closer bonds among students and the program's institutional management, faculty, and alumni. Project activities also are making substantive contributions to research in undergraduate engineering education by providing opportunities to validate existing activities and measuring the effectiveness of new ones. The evaluation effort, which is being performed by a specialist in the UVa School of Education and Center for Institutional Assessment and Studies, is tracking the number of participants, their academic progress, and their response to the project's activities. Broader impacts include the interactions among the students and faculty members at a major university and a community college and the increase in the number and diversity of well prepared engineering graduates.

Institution.Name: University of Virginia Main Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the STEP-ACES grant was to increase the number of students, especially underrepresented minority students that enter and earn baccalaureate degrees in Engineering.  Furthermore, we aim to recruit undergraduate engineering students to UVA from our partner institution, Thomas Nelson Community College. To this end, we focused on the following goals:

  • SEAS year-one-to-year-two retention rate;
  • SEAS 5-year graduation rate;
  • TNCC's transfer rate;
  • and TNCC’s three-year graduation rate.

UVA SEAS 5-Year Graduation Rate.  STEP-ACES aimed to increase SEAS 5-year graduation rate by 2% each year with a starting baseline value of 72%.  Over the lifetime of the grant, this goal was accomplished and 91.9% of the Fall 2009 SEAS cohort graduated within 5 years.  This vaule exceeds the 60.8% of students that persist to earn a Bachelor’s degree in Engineering over six-years. This grant also increased the graduation rates for traditionally underrepresented populations in engineering as detailed below for the 2009 cohort.

  • Females - 95%
  • African Americans - 86.7%
  • Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islanders - 100%
  • Hispanic Americans - 82.4%
  • Multi-race (100%) 

UVA SEAS Yearly Retention Rate: STEP-ACES set forth to increase SEAS year 1-2 retention rates by 2% each year for five years with a baseline value of 88%.  The year 1 to year 2 and year 2 to year 3 retention rates have exceeded the original 88% maximum stated in the proposal with values greater than 90% for all populations. Furthermore, year two to year three retention rates are above 90% on average for all groups.  

TNCC 3-Year Graduation: On average ~25% of students entering the engineering curriculum at TNCC finish. Thus the STEP-ACES goal of 50% was not met. There are a number of factors that attribute to this decreased completion rates at community colleges. 

TNCC Transfer Rate: The fourth aim of this grant was to increase the transfer rate between students from Thomas Nelson Community College and four-year institutions by two percent each year over a five-year period using a baseline value of 50%. The transfer rate exceeded 90% in 2010 with a majority of students electing to attend another 4-year instituition in Virginia. 

Based on the data above, we were able to meet and exceed a majority of our goals for the STEP-ACES grant through the implementation of some best practices which include, but are not limited to: a summer transition program for entiering freshman, tutoring, undergraduate research, Community College Day, workshops, and seminars.  Beyond the original goals set forth, the STEP-ACES grants activites also impacted the post-graduate outcomes for students.  At least 25 students from underrepresented populations that participated in the summer REU program or as a tutor have gone on to attend graduate school in STEM or STEM education to obtain a Masters or Doctoral degree.  To this end, a number of the practices that have been implemented will be continued beyong the life of the grant to ensure that engineers are created to a part of the 21st century workforce.  


Last Modified: 12/03/2014
Modified by: Carolyn Vallas

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The overarching goal of the STEP-ACES grant was to increase the number of students, especially underrepresented minority students that enter and earn baccalaureate degrees in Engineering. Furthermore, we aim to recruit undergraduate engineering students to UVA from our partner institution, Thomas Nelson Community College. To this end, we focused on the following goals: SEAS year-one-to-year-two retention rate; SEAS 5-year graduation rate; TNCC's transfer rate; and TNCCÆs three-year graduation rate. UVA SEAS 5-Year Graduation Rate. STEP-ACES aimed to increase SEAS 5-year graduation rate by 2% each year with a starting baseline value of 72%. Over the lifetime of the grant, this goal was accomplished and 91.9% of the Fall 2009 SEAS cohort graduated within 5 years. This vaule exceeds the 60.8% of students that persist to earn a BachelorÆs degree in Engineering over six-years. This grant also increased the graduation rates for traditionally underrepresented populations in engineering as detailed below for the 2009 cohort. Females - 95% African Americans - 86.7% Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islanders - 100% Hispanic Americans - 82.4% Multi-race (100%) UVA SEAS Yearly Retention Rate: STEP-ACES set forth to increase SEAS year 1-2 retention rates by 2% each year for five years with a baseline value of 88%. The year 1 to year 2 and year 2 to year 3 retention rates have exceeded the original 88% maximum stated in the proposal with values greater than 90% for all populations. Furthermore, year two to year three retention rates are above 90% on average for all groups. TNCC 3-Year Graduation: On average ~25% of students entering the engineering curriculum at TNCC finish. Thus the STEP-ACES goal of 50% was not met. There are a number of factors that attribute to this decreased completion rates at community colleges. TNCC Transfer Rate: The fourth aim of this grant was to increase the transfer rate between students from Thomas Nelson Community College and four-year institutions by two percent each year over a five-year period using a baseline value of 50%. The transfer rate exceeded 90% in 2010 with a majority of students electing to attend another 4-year instituition in Virginia. Based on the data above, we were able to meet and exceed a majority of our goals for the STEP-ACES grant through the implementation of some best practices which include, but are not limited to: a summer transition program for entiering freshman, tutoring, undergraduate research, Community College Day, workshops, and seminars. Beyond the original goals set forth, the STEP-ACES grants activites also impacted the post-graduate outcomes for students. At least 25 students from underrepresented populations that participated in the summer REU program or as a tutor have gone on to attend graduate school in STEM or STEM education to obtain a Masters or Doctoral degree. To this end, a number of the practices that have been implemented will be continued beyong the life of the grant to ensure that engineers are created to a part of the 21st century workforce.
